comments.author: Nat Cat

comments.text:
This is the polar opposite of what I was expecting.  Isn't there a plethora 
of information besmirching the printed use by dates in favour of good old 
common (smell) sense? I'm not advocating that we just ignore the 
information, but I've eaten eggs up to four months past their 'prime' and 
suffered no ill effects.  Just stick 'em in a bowl of water.  If they sink, 
they're fine.  If they float, bin 'em (gases build up over time.) But I 
honestly don't believe that there's any time limit to apply to consumables 
- unless they smell or look 'iffy.'  Anyway, my dad was never exactly a 
shiny-shiny kitchen magician, so maybe my sister and I just have developed 
a hardy immune system over the years.  Conclusion - give it a sniff!!  Give 
it a gandersnort...﻿

comments.author: Sammy The Yandere

comments.text:
Oh hells no! I just ate two-week old cold cuts yesterday! I'll be damned if 
I'm going to throw away good salami after five days! I call bullshit. I've 
eaten three-week old Genoa salami more times than I can count and it's 
always good. By the way, the Provolone I put on my sandwich has been in my 
refrigerator for a week and a half and the mustard for like three months. 
Yes, the bread was new but that's just because Focaccia rolls go stale 
after a few days and I can just run to the supermarket to get a couple 
whenever I need them. So yeah, okay, the bread and lettuce had to be fresh. 
But there is no way the meat and cheese were not perfectly fine to eat.﻿
